content: The Physician Self-Referral Amendments of 1999 Act is also known as the "Physician Self-Referral Amendments of 1999". The table of contents for this Act is provided. The Physician Self-Referral Amendments of 1999 Act, also known as the "Physician Self-Referral Amendments of 1999", includes provisions such as eliminating restrictions on physician referrals based on compensation arrangements, exceptions to ownership referral prohibitions, changes in the definition of group practice, and exclusion of certain medical devices. It also allows for the supervision of clinical laboratory services by independent contractor pathologists. Eliminating restrictions on physician referrals based on compensation arrangements is a key provision of the Physician Self-Referral Amendments of 1999 Act. The Physician Self-Referral Amendments of 1999 Act eliminates restrictions on physician referrals based on ownership or investment interests in entities through equity. Subsection (e) is struck, and changes are made to subsection (f) regarding ownership and investment. In subsection (h), paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) are removed, and changes are made to paragraph (4) by eliminating clause (iv) and revising the rules for faculty. SEC. 3. EXCEPTIONS TO OWNERSHIP REFERRAL PROHIBITIONS. Revisions to Exception for In-Office Ancillary Services include repealing the site-of-service requirement in Section 1877 of the Social Security Act. Services must be personally furnished by the referring physician, a physician in the same group practice, or individuals under their supervision. The new paragraph added to subsection (h) defines "general supervision" as the physician being legally responsible for services performed by an individual, ensuring licensure and certification requirements are met, regardless of physical presence during service provision. The text chunk discusses amendments to the treatment of physician owners of group practices and clarifications regarding ancillary services furnished personally or through group practice. It also addresses exceptions for services furnished in a rural area. Amendment to Section 1877(d)(2) of the Act requires not less than 75 percent ownership for physician owners of group practices. SEC. 4. CHANGE IN DEFINITION OF GROUP PRACTICE. Section 1877(h)(4) of the Social Security Act is amended to define a physician as a 'member' of a group if they are an owner or employee of the group. SEC. 5 delays the implementation of ownership referral changes from the 1993 Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act until final regulations are issued. SEC. 6 excludes intraocular lenses, eyeglasses, and contact lenses. SEC. 6 amends the Social Security Act to exclude intraocular lenses, eyeglasses, and contact lenses. SEC. 7 allows pathologists who are independent contractors to supervise clinical laboratory services. Section 1877(b)(2) of the Social Security Act is amended to include pathologists supervising clinical laboratory services in a group practice. The effective date for the amendments made by this Act is for referrals made on or after the enactment date, regardless of regulations being in place.
